Propositional logic 2

Extended truth tables

Erik Hoversten

Rutgers university: LRP, fall 2014

October 27, 2014

Truth tables

The meaning of propositions

  • In propositional logic, the complete meaning of a proposition is given by its truth table
  • This is because the truth table shows all the possible situations across which the formula's truth value can vary.
    • Thus, it gives the truth conditions for that formula.

Basic propositions

  • Let's call the formulas that we can form through the simplest application of the syntax rules the basic propositions
    • These propositions contain no more than 1 connective.
  • Basic propositions in our language:
    • Atomic propositions
    • Negations
    • Conjunctions
    • Disjunctions
    • Conditionals
    • Biconditionals

Truth tables for basic propositions

p ~p
T F
F T
p q p ∙ q
T T T
T F F
F T F
F F F
p q p ∨ q
T T T
T F T
F T T
F F F
p q p ⊃ q
T T T
T F F
F T T
F F T

Complex propositions

  • Let's call any WFF that is built from multiple applications of the syntax rules a complex proposition.
    • Complex propositions contain at least 2 connectives.
  • Complex propositions are built up recursively from basic propositions.
    • Thus, we can construct the truth table for a complex proposition by putting together truth tables of basic propositions.
  • Examples:
    • (A ∙ B) ∨ (E ⊃ F)
    • (~A ∨ ~B)
    • ~(A ≡ B) ⊃ C

Complex truth tables

Construct the columns

  • Add a column for every distinct propositional variable occurring in the WFF
  • Add a column for every distinct basic proposition occurring in the WFF.
      Start with the smallest propositions and work your way out.
  • Add a column for the complete WFF
  • Example:
    • ~(A ≡ B) ⊃ C
p q r (p ≡ q) ~(p ≡ q) ~(p ≡ q) ⊃ r

Complex truth tables

Construct the rows

  • Ensure you have all possible combinations of truth values for the WFF. (2n rule)
  • Fill the columns for propositional variables. (divide by 2 rule)
p q r (p ≡ q) ~(p ≡ q) ~(p ≡ q) ⊃ r
TTT
TTF
TFT
TFF
FTT
FTF
FFT
FFF

Complex truth tables

Fill the rows

  • Fill the columns for the basic propositions using the truth tables we constructed above.
  • Then treat those basic propositions as individual propositional variables when they occur in other columns
  • Fill the columns for complex propositions using the columns you already filled for the basic propositions contained in them.
  • Continue this process until all the columns are filled.

Complex truth tables

Complete example: ~(p ≡ q) ⊃ r

p q r (p ≡ q) ~(p ≡ q) ~(p ≡ q) ⊃ r
TTT TFT
TTF TFT
TFT FTT
TFF FTF
FTT FTT
FTF FTF
FFT TFT
FFF TFT

Complex truth tables

Complete example: (p ⊃ q) ∙ (q ⊃ p)

p q p ⊃ q q ⊃ p (p ⊃ q) ∙ (q ⊃ p)
TT TTT
TF FTF
FT TFF
FF TTT

Notice that this table is identical to the table for the biconditional. This shows that (p ⊃ q) ∙ (q ⊃ p) means the same thing as p ≡ q
